comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: What a great image - I wonder where it is?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Yes, it's rather ominous, isn't it, especially with that shadowy figure of the lone guard. This photo is in a run of other gaol images, various gaols (one unidentified) and then a series of unidentified interiors. You can see the others under Photo Investigator -> Subject Search -> P -> Prisons AB

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Thanks for that link - I see that there is another unidentified gaol interior with similar fittings but three floors. Both have barrel vault ceilings, which might provide a clue - most gaols seem to have hipped roofs. investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I think the three level photo and possibly this one too, may be Goulburn Gaol. See middle photo at the bottom of this page - www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_01_2.cfm?itemid=5000652 . That would also date the photo as 1884, or if it the new wing 1893.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: It looks like the same interior...you certainly know your Gaols beachcomberaustralia :)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I did some more research on Goulburn Gaol, and am now sure this is part of a series photographed in 1884 when the (new) Goulburn Gaol was nearing completion, but not yet open for inmates. Probably done as James Barnet the Government Architect's visual record, in very similar style, quality, and time period as the Callan Park / Gladesville photos. There are a couple of Goulburn Gaol photos in the State Library (via the Government Printing Office) which are different but from the same series (imho) - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=168078 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=168079 The second photo has to be a reverse view of this 3-tier "unidentified gaol interior" (mentioned above) - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... The "unidentified gaol chapel" - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... is most likely the building at the centre of the complex, mentioned in the Heritage NSW site above. There are several identified exterior views of Goulburn Gaol under construction (ie 1884) - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... And one which is wrongly identified (imho) - no hipped roofs at Goulburn - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... These two are a mystery - the style of the doors and interior are different, and there are signs of wear and tear on the walls and handrails. I wonder if they are photos of the OLD gaol at Goulburn or Bathurst? - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp...

comment.author: 73259633@N07
comment._content: The photo link above the phrase ''unidentified gaol chapel'' appears on page 458 of the Report of the Royal Commission into N.S.W.Prisons.1976-77-78 with the line ''B Wing Goulburn Gaol about 1900.There is little change today''.
